title: 112_hr1591
content: The Act may be cited as the "Sanctity of Eternal Rest for Veterans Act of 2011" or the "SERVE Act of 2011." The purpose and authority are outlined in Section 2. The "Sanctity of Eternal Rest for Veterans Act of 2011" or the "SERVE Act of 2011" aims to support the recruitment and retention of the Armed Forces and militia by protecting their dignity and privacy during funeral services. Congress deems this Act as a necessary exercise of its constitutional powers. Section 1388 of title 18, United States Code is amended to prohibit disruptions of funerals of members or former members of the armed forces. It is unlawful for any person to engage in activities near such funerals within specific time and distance limits. The amended Section 1388 of title 18, United States Code prohibits disruptions of funerals of armed forces members. It is illegal to engage in activities near such funerals within specific time and distance limits, including making noise or causing disturbances. The amended Section 1388 of title 18, United States Code prohibits disruptions of funerals of armed forces members by individuals causing disturbances. Violators may face fines or imprisonment for up to 2 years. Civil remedies allow for legal action to prevent violations and seek relief for any injuries suffered. The amended Section 1388 of title 18, United States Code allows the deceased person's immediate family to sue in court for damages and legal costs if they suffer injury from violations. A final judgment in a criminal proceeding estops the defendant from denying allegations in a subsequent civil proceeding. Damages can include actual and statutory penalties. In addition to penalties, violators of Section 1388 of title 18, United States Code may face liability for damages in civil actions. Private individuals can seek actual or statutory damages for violations, while the Attorney General can also pursue statutory damages. Courts have the authority to award statutory damages in such cases. Courts may award statutory damages ranging from $25,000 to $50,000 per violation. There is a rebuttable presumption of willful violation if the violator did not have reasonable grounds to believe their conduct would not disturb the peace at a funeral. The section defines "Armed Forces" and "immediate family" for the purpose of the law. SEC. 4. AMENDMENT TO TITLE 38. Section 2413 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to prohibit demonstrations and disruptions at cemeteries under the control of the National Cemetery Administration and at Arlington National Cemetery without prior approval. It is also unlawful to engage in activities near a funeral, memorial service, or ceremony held at these cemeteries. The amended Section 2413 of title 38, United States Code prohibits demonstrations and disruptions at cemeteries under the control of the National Cemetery Administration and at Arlington National Cemetery without prior approval. It also prohibits activities near a funeral, memorial service, or ceremony held at these cemeteries within specific distances. The amended Section 2413 of title 38, United States Code prohibits disruptions at cemeteries under the control of the National Cemetery Administration and at Arlington National Cemetery without prior approval. It also prohibits activities near a funeral, memorial service, or ceremony held at these cemeteries within specific distances. Violators may face fines or imprisonment, and civil remedies are available for those affected by such conduct. Violators of Section 2413 of title 38, United States Code may be sued in court and liable for damages, including attorneys' fees. A final judgment in a criminal proceeding estops the defendant from denying the offense in a subsequent civil proceeding. In addition to penalties, violators are liable for actual or statutory damages in civil actions. A person bringing an action under subsection (c)(3) may elect to recover actual damages or statutory damages for each violation. The Attorney General is entitled to statutory damages for each violation. Courts may award statutory damages ranging from $25,000 to $50,000 per violation. There is a rebuttable presumption of willful violation if reasonable cause is not shown. The section defines prohibited conduct at funerals, memorial services, or ceremonies, including disturbances to peace, impeding access, disrupting funeral processions. Demonstrations encompass picketing, speeches, or similar activities not part of the event. The section prohibits disturbances at funerals, memorial services, or ceremonies, including picketing, banners, and distributing written materials. Prohibition on disruptions at cemeteries under National Cemetery Administration and Arlington National Cemetery.
